sections.title: What are relative pronouns?
sections.content:
Relative pronouns (who, which, that, where, when, whose) introduce a relative clause that tells us more about a noun.

Examples:
• The woman **who** lives next door is a doctor. (person)
• The book **which/that** I'm reading is very good. (thing)
• This is the house **where** I was born. (place)
• I remember the day **when** we first met. (time)
• The person **whose** bag was stolen reported it. (possession)

sections.title: Which relative pronoun to use
sections.content:
• **Who** (or **that**) – for people: the man who/that I saw.
• **Which** or **that** – for things: the book which/that I read.
• **Where** – for places: the town where I grew up. (Or: the town that/which I grew up in.)
• **When** – for time: the day when we met. (Or: the day that we met.)
• **Whose** – for possession: the girl whose bike was stolen.

In defining relative clauses we can often omit the pronoun when it is the object: The book (that) I read was good.

sections.title: That vs which
sections.content:
**Defining clause** (essential, no comma): The book **that/which** I lent you is on the table. Use **that** or **which** for things.

**Non-defining clause** (extra info, with comma): This book, **which** I bought yesterday, is good. Prague, **which** is the capital, is beautiful. Use **which** only — never **that** after a comma.

**Rule:** No comma → that or which. Comma (extra info) → **which** only.

After **everything, something, anything:** Everything **that** he said was true. (That is more natural than which.)

sections.title: Typical mistakes
sections.content:
• **Which for people:** Wrong: The woman *which* lives next door. Right: The woman **who/that** lives next door. (Which = things only.)
• **That after comma:** Wrong: Prague, *that* is the capital, is beautiful. Right: Prague, **which** is the capital, is beautiful.
• **Everything/something:** Everything **that** he said (that is natural here).
• **Comma for extra info:** My car, **which** is ten years old, still works. (Comma = extra info; use which.)

Summary: People → who or that. Things, no comma → that or which. Things, with comma → which only.

sections.title: Don't use 'what' as relative pronoun
sections.content:
In English we do **not** use **what** after a noun (Czech 'co'):

• Wrong: The book *what* I read. Right: The book **that/which** I read.
• Wrong: The man *what* I saw. Right: The man **who/that** I saw.
• Wrong: The house *what* I was born in. Right: The house **where** I was born (or that/which I was born in).

**What** = 'the thing(s) that' (no noun before it): **What** I need is a holiday.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Never what** after a noun. Use which/that (things), who/that (people), where (place), when (time).
• People → who or that. Things, no comma → that or which. Things, comma → which only.
• The book *what* I read → The book **that/which** I read. The person *what* I met → **who/that** I met.
• **What** alone = 'the thing that': What I said was true.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: The book that I read was interesting.
options.b: The book what I read was interesting.
options.c: The book what I read it was interesting.
options.d: The book I read what was interesting.

questions.explanation: We use **that** or **which** for things in a relative clause, not **what**.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: The woman what lives next door is a doctor.
options.b: The woman what she lives next door is a doctor.
options.c: The woman who lives next door is a doctor.
options.d: The woman which lives next door is a doctor.

questions.explanation: We use **who** (or **that**) for people, not **what** or **which**.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: This is the town what I was born.
options.b: This is the town what I was born in.
options.c: This is the town who I was born.
options.d: This is the town where I was born.

questions.explanation: For places we use **where** (or 'the town that/which I was born in'), not **what**.

questions.question: When is 'what' correct in a relative sense?

options.a: What I need is more time.
options.b: The film what we saw was good.
options.c: The thing what I said was wrong.
options.d: The person what helped me left.

questions.explanation: **What** means 'the thing(s) that' and starts its own clause (What I need = The thing that I need). We don't use **what** after a noun.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: The day what we met was sunny.
options.b: The day what we met on was sunny.
options.c: The day when we met was sunny.
options.d: The day who we met was sunny.

questions.explanation: For time we use **when** (or 'the day that we met'), not **what**.

gapfill.title: Practice: Choose the correct relative pronoun

questions.question: The book ____ I'm reading is by a Czech author.
answers: that
which
questions.explanation: For things we use **that** or **which**, not **what**.

questions.question: The woman ____ lives next door is very kind.
answers: who
that
questions.explanation: For people (subject of the clause) we use **who** or **that**.

questions.question: This is the house ____ I was born.
answers: where
questions.explanation: For place we use **where** (or 'that/which I was born in').

questions.question: The man ____ I spoke to was the manager.
answers: who
that
whom
questions.explanation: For people (object) we use **who**, **that**, or **whom**; we can also omit: The man I spoke to.

questions.question: I don't remember the day ____ we first met.
answers: when
that
questions.explanation: For time we use **when** or **that**, not **what**.

questions.question: The film ____ we saw yesterday was boring.
answers: that
which
questions.explanation: For things we use **that** or **which**, never **what** after a noun.

questions.question: The person ____ phone was stolen called the police.
answers: whose
questions.explanation: For possession we use **whose** (whose phone = the phone of whom).

questions.question: The town ____ I grew up is very small.
answers: where
questions.explanation: For place we use **where** (or 'that/which I grew up in').

questions.question: The teacher ____ taught us English has retired.
answers: who
that
questions.explanation: For people (subject) we use **who** or **that**.

questions.question: Everything ____ he said was true.
answers: that
questions.explanation: After 'everything', 'something', 'anything' we use **that** (or omit). We don't use **what** here.

questions.question: The reason ____ I'm late is the traffic.
answers: why
that
questions.explanation: For reason we often use **why** or **that** (the reason why/that I'm late).

questions.question: The hotel ____ we stayed was very comfortable.
answers: where
that
which
questions.explanation: For place we use **where** or **that/which** (the hotel where we stayed / that we stayed at).

errorcorrection.title: Practice: Correct the relative pronoun (Czech-style errors)

questions.question: Wrong: The book what I read was very long. Correct the sentence.
answers: The book that I read was very long.
The book which I read was very long.
The book that I read was very long
The book which I read was very long
questions.explanation: Use **that** or **which** for things, never **what** after a noun.

questions.question: Wrong: The man what I met yesterday is a doctor. Correct the sentence.
answers: The man who I met yesterday is a doctor.
The man that I met yesterday is a doctor.
The man who I met yesterday is a doctor
The man that I met yesterday is a doctor
questions.explanation: Use **who** or **that** for people, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: This is the house what I was born in. Correct the sentence.
answers: This is the house where I was born.
This is the house that I was born in.
This is the house which I was born in.
This is the house where I was born
This is the house that I was born in
This is the house which I was born in
questions.explanation: Use **where** or **that/which I was born in**, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: The film what we saw was really good. Correct the sentence.
answers: The film that we saw was really good.
The film which we saw was really good.
The film that we saw was really good
The film which we saw was really good
questions.explanation: For things use **that** or **which**, never **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: The woman what works here is from Prague. Correct the sentence.
answers: The woman who works here is from Prague.
The woman that works here is from Prague.
The woman who works here is from Prague
The woman that works here is from Prague
questions.explanation: For people use **who** or **that**, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: I don't like the things what he said. Correct the sentence.
answers: I don't like the things that he said.
I don't like what he said.
I don't like the things that he said
I don't like what he said
questions.explanation: After 'the things' use **that** (or omit). Or use **What he said** (the thing that he said) as the object.

questions.question: Wrong: The place what we stayed was very nice. Correct the sentence.
answers: The place where we stayed was very nice.
The place that we stayed at was very nice.
The place which we stayed at was very nice.
The place where we stayed was very nice
The place that we stayed at was very nice
The place which we stayed at was very nice
questions.explanation: For place use **where** or **that/which we stayed at**, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: The day what we arrived was Monday. Correct the sentence.
answers: The day when we arrived was Monday.
The day that we arrived was Monday.
The day when we arrived was Monday
The day that we arrived was Monday
questions.explanation: For time use **when** or **that**, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: The person what helped me was very kind. Correct the sentence.
answers: The person who helped me was very kind.
The person that helped me was very kind.
The person who helped me was very kind
The person that helped me was very kind
questions.explanation: For people (subject) use **who** or **that**, not **what**.

questions.question: Wrong: That's the reason what I left. Correct the sentence.
answers: That's the reason why I left.
That's the reason that I left.
That's the reason why I left
That's the reason that I left
questions.explanation: For reason use **why** or **that**, not **what**.
